components.name: eucanetd
components.description: Used to track component level items associated with Edge.

fields.description:
The init script for eucanetd needs to check for and enforce that the sysctl config files are enabling bridge-nf-call-iptables. This causes networking to fail in EDGE mode when it gets set to 0. 

[root@g-15-01 ~]# sysctl -A | grep bridge-nf-call-iptables
net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables = 1
[root@g-15-01 ~]#
fields.summary: Calls to IPtables for bridge interfaces can be disabled by sysctl

comments.body:
I fixed this by doing:
 sysctl net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables=1

The init script should check for all the places where  net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables could be enabled and fail to start the service if its not set properly.

There is some more context on this issue, which I think should be addressed as part of this specific case.  

- in MANAGED* modes, net.ipv4.ip_forward must be set to '1' on all CCs
- in MANAGED* modes, if your CCs have an interface that is a bridge, net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables must be set to '1' on all CCs
- in ALL networking modes,  net.ipv4.ip_forward and net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables must be set to '1' on all NCs

simplest would be to always set both of those params to '1' on all CCs and NCs, regardless of networking mode.  The init scripts for Eucalyptus currently poke '1's into /proc for these settings, but they are not made permanent until the params are set in /etc/sysctl.conf.  More and more, we're encountering scenarios where something in the system is resetting sysctl parameters at runtime based on what is in /etc/sysctl.conf, so it is important to get these set correctly.

The consequence of not setting them, and at some point having something in the system reset sysctl params from the /etc/sysctl.conf settings, is varied, but will certainly have a negative effect on VM networking.

-D

[~gholms] [~nurmi]

So to fix this we need to:

1) Make sure to document this extra configuration
2) Stop the NC and CC init script from starting the service in the cases that [~nurmi] describes above

Anything else to do?

[~nurmi]

In talking with [~gholms] we are thinking that persistently setting this *for* users is going to be too complex since /etc/sysctl.conf takes precedence over anything we might provide ourselves, so people would need to check their configs anyway.

Can the NC/CC periodically check this value and go to a disabled state if its set to 0? I think we can assert that these components need admin intervention in order to function properly if the params are not set right. Either way we go we need to document these to settings.

I suggest the following:

in eucalyptus-cc and eucalyptus-nc init scripts, run the 'apply_sysctl' routine (defined in /etc/init.d/functions), like /etc/init.d/network does, and then check the values that have been set for net.ipv4.ip_forward and net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables.  If they are not set properly after 'apply_sysctl', then the init scripts should refuse to start the service, instead displaying an error message informing the admin that they need to set these values in /etc/sysctl.conf properly.  This has the downside of the system not running 'by default' since those values are set to 0 in sysctl.conf by default (in rhel/centos).  

A slight modification would be the same as above, but instead of having the init script error and not start the service, simply output a WARNING before setting the values explicitly and then starting the service.  This way, the system would still start up and function even when /etc/sysctl.conf has disabled values, but it would WARN the admin whenever the init script is invoked that there is a potential for the runtime values being reset by some other process after the services are started.

I would go with the latter (run apply_sysctl, check values, if they're 0 output a big WARNING plus set the values to 1 and start the service)

-D

proposed fix in team/network/edge (commit acb3e91ae2355860ea14697fa6f8ca94a913c4be)

[~viglesias], [~gholms], can you please review?

summary: in eucalyptus-cc, eucalyptus-nc, and eucanetd init scripts, replace the current ip_forward/bridge-nf-call-iptables tweaking code with the following (same in all three):

{code}
        # logic to detect if required proc parameters will be reset by                                                                                                                                         
        # a sysctl update: succeed and continue if default values are                                                                                                                                          
        # correct, succeed but warn the user if the default settings                                                                                                                                           
        # are incorrect (and set them, and continue), fail if the                                                                                                                                              
        # values cannot be set                                                                                                                                                                                 
        for CHECKVAR in /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward /proc/sys/net/bridge/bridge-nf-call-iptables
        do
            if [ -r "$CHECKVAR" ]; then
                # first, apply sysctl settings (set in /etc/sysctl*)                                                                                                                                           
                apply_sysctl
                VAL=`cat $CHECKVAR`

                # if either the value is disabled after a sysctl reset, WARN the user, set it, and continue                                                                                                    
                if [ "$VAL" = "0" ]; then
                    echo
                    echo "WARN: ${CHECKVAR}=0 (disabled) after a sysctl reset: check /etc/sysctl.conf settings to enable them by default."
                    if [ -w "$CHECKVAR" ]; then
                        echo "Setting ${CHECKVAR}=1"
                        echo -n 1 > ${CHECKVAR}
                    else
                        echo "Cannot enable (write to) ${CHECKVAR}: check permissions"
                        exit 1
                    fi
                fi
            else
                echo
                echo "Cannot read required proc value ${CHECKVAR}: check permissions"
                exit 1
            fi
        done
{code}

synced with Vic and TimC:

commit 91251ee9895ee387abc66e270c676dcf498139c2
Author: Daniel Nurmi <nurmi@eucalyptus.com>
Date:   Fri May 2 14:56:59 2014 -0700

    latest merge from team/network/edge: fixes EUCA-9298 and EUCA-8957

[~nurmi],

Is there any reason why we wouldn't just set the values whenever Edge mode is being used on the NC?  I know the cloud admin can do it manually, but I figured if its something we know we need for Edge to work correctly, should we just do it upon start up of eucalyptus-nc, and just have messages that state what values we changed in /etc/sysctl.conf?

[~hspencer], [~viglesias] and [~gholms] I believe cautioned against this behavior as a technical solution, since there are a variety of ways to set values for sysctl (/etc/sysctl.conf is one of them, but there are other places in /etc/sysctl.d/ where the same can be done, with override semantics being unclear).  The decision, then, was to refrain from modifying /etc files from the init script or package install, but to WARN and set the runtime parameter as described.

-D

[~nurmi],

Ah ok, understood.  Should we add a DOC ticket so that cloud admins know what to set as you mentioned [earlier|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-8957?focusedCommentId=66095&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-66095]?

I just performed an upgrade from 3.4.2 to 4.0 and ran into this. I could not reach instances so checked the NC.  When the service restarted I got the warning and edited /etc/sysctl.conf accordingly and I could once again reach instances.  The setup is using managed-novlan. The CC had the proper settings for /etc/sysctl.conf.  Am I reading all the comments correctly that this is now the expected behavior: the admin will need to properly set the values in /etc/sysctl.conf?
